subject: Re: Order of execution
msgSnippet: ... test. ... systems) ... experience, ... and ... as ... If you need the tests to run in a certain order, build the test suite yourself. Remember, folks:
messageBody:
--- In junit@y..., "Wolfgang Egger" <beuys@b...> wrote:
> Servus Nahan,
>
> -----Original Message-----
> From: Paris, Nathan x66165 [mailto:nathan_paris@a...]
> Sent: Friday, November 29, 2002 9:44 PM
> To: 'junit@y...'
> Subject: RE: [junit] Order of execution
>
>
> There is no guarantee that they will run in the order of the
> test file and
> you should not write your tests in a way that depends on this.
> You should
> use the setUp and tearDown methods to properly setup each
test.
>
>
> I know that this is the "pure doctrine". But what do you do, if you
> have a series of dependent test (some interaction between two
systems)
> that need a defined protocoll and therefor a defined order?
>
> You may say, these kind of tests ar no unit-tests, but in my
experience,
> you most of the time need many kind of tests within one application
and
> i like to make it comfortable and to have one TestSuite to control
as
> may tests as possible from one place.

If you need the tests to run in a certain order, build the test suite
yourself.

Remember, folks: naming your test methods "testSomething()" is ONLY a
NAMING CONVENTION to help JUnit create test suites automatically.
Otherwise, build the test suite yourself!

See my article JUnit: A Starter Guide for details.
